did.unittitle: Hemlock Society of the Delaware Valley records

bioghist.p: The Hemlock Society was founded in 1980 as an end-of-life care organization for those suffering with incurable illnesses. in 2003, the Society, after surveying its membership, enhanced its mission to include a more proactive effort in introducing and changing laws that allow people the right to choose a peaceful hastened death if they are terminally ill and mentally competent. As a result of this, the board of directors changed the society's name to End-of-Life Choices.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records of the Hemlock Society of Delaware Valley, 1992 to 1996. Materials include: newsletters from the national organization, the Delaware Valley chapter, and from several other regional chapters, including Michigan, Oregon, New Jersey, and Northern California; newspaper clippings and photocopies of articles; a membership list; letters to members; promotional material; materials related to meetings and conferences, including the Celebrate Age Expo (1995) and the National Conference on Voluntary Euthanasia (1994); a copy of Society's 1993 publication "Cases of Euthanasia, Mercy Killing, Suicide, and Assisted Suicide"; and copies of euthanasia-related legislation.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: College of Physicians of Philadelphia: Hemlock Society of Delaware Valley records and Hemlock Society records (MSS 3/0022-01).
